channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SEC-2546] provide springSecurityFilterChain-like functionality for websocket security
item.description:
just wanted to raise the idea of leveraging the channelInterceptor concept of spring messaging to allow securing websocket communication in a spring-security like fashion.

for inspirational purposes i pasted some groovy code that was created while playing with grails' spring-websocket plugin trying to secure the messaging below. it shows a ChannelInterceptor bean. ofc this is not even close to some realistic approach (the permission mappings inside the bean, using closures, dummy permissions, etc.) but i think it shows that the basic idea of using ChannelInterceptors for security is not too far off track?

// src/groovy/websocket/SecurityChannelInterceptor.groovy
 
 
package websocket
 
 
import grails.plugin.springsecurity.SpringSecurityService
 
import groovy.transform.CompileStatic
 
import groovy.util.logging.Log4j
 
 
import javax.annotation.PostConstruct
 
import javax.annotation.Resource
 
 
import org.springframework.messaging.Message
 
import org.springframework.messaging.MessageChannel
 
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.SimpMessageType
 
import org.springframework.messaging.simp.stomp.StompHeaderAccessor
 
import org.springframework.messaging.support.AbstractSubscribableChannel
 
import org.springframework.messaging.support.ChannelInterceptorAdapter
 
import org.springframework.security.core.Authentication
 
import org.springframework.security.core.context.SecurityContextHolder
 
import org.springframework.util.AntPathMatcher
 
 
@CompileStatic
 
@Log4j
 
class SecurityChannelInterceptor extends ChannelInterceptorAdapter {
 
 
    @Resource
 
    AbstractSubscribableChannel clientInboundChannel
 
 
    @Resource
 
    SpringSecurityService springSecurityService
 
 
    AntPathMatcher matcher = new AntPathMatcher()
 
     
    Map<SimpMessageType, ? extends Map<String, Closure>> permissions = [
 
        (SimpMessageType.SUBSCRIBE): [
 
            "/topic/hello": { true },
 
            "/user/queue/helloSecured": { springSecurityService.loggedIn },
 
            "/user/queue/helloSecured-*": { Message message ->
 
                if (!springSecurityService.loggedIn) return false
 
                def id = StompHeaderAccessor.wrap(message).destination - "/user/queue/helloSecured-"
 
                id == "123"
 
            }
 
        ],
 
        (SimpMessageType.MESSAGE): [
 
            "/app/hello": { true },
 
            "/app/helloSecured": { springSecurityService.loggedIn },
 
            "/app/helloSecured-*": { Message message ->
 
                if (!springSecurityService.loggedIn) return false
 
                def id = StompHeaderAccessor.wrap(message).destination - "/app/helloSecured-"
 
                id == "123"
 
            }
 
        ]
 
    ]
 
     
    @PostConstruct
 
    void init() {
 
        clientInboundChannel.addInterceptor this
 
    }
 
     
    @Override
 
    Message<?> preSend(Message<?> message, MessageChannel channel) {
 
        def headers = StompHeaderAccessor.wrap message
 
         
        def destination = headers.destination
 
        // pass the message through if no destination header is found (e.g. for heartbeat messages)
 
        if (!destination) return message
 
         
        def messageType = headers.messageType
 
        Map<String, Closure> messageTypePermissions = permissions[messageType]
 
        // pass the message through if no messageType mapping is found (e.g. for CONNECT frames)
 
        if (!messageTypePermissions) return message
 
         
        // reject/ignore the message if no permission mapping is found (whitelisting)
 
        def allowed = false
 
         
        for (permissionMapping in messageTypePermissions.entrySet()) {
 
            if (matcher.match(permissionMapping.key, destination)) {
 
                def authentication = (Authentication) headers.user
 
                def oldAuthentication = SecurityContextHolder.context.authentication
 
                SecurityContextHolder.context.authentication = authentication
 
                 
                try {
 
                    allowed = permissionMapping.value.call(message)
 
                } catch (e) {
 
                    log.error "error evaluating permission mapping for pattern ${permissionMapping.key} (${e.message})"
 
                } finally {
 
                    SecurityContextHolder.context.authentication = oldAuthentication
 
                }
 
                 
                break
 
            }
 
        }
 
        Message<?> result = allowed ? message : null
 
        return result
 
    }
 
 
}

fwiw, this jira should perhaps be linked to SEC-2179
item.summary: provide springSecurityFilterChain-like functionality for websocket security

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Thanks for the sample code. I updated the title of SEC-2179 as it should not be investigate but implement. I will move this as a child for the moment, but it is more likely a duplicate now that I have renamed it.
I'm marking this as a duplicate of SEC-2671
This issue has been migrated to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/2758
